factoid: The generals listened reluctantly to the difficult dispositions.
General Buxhöwden stood leaning his back against the wall.
General Buxhöwden's eyes were fixed on a burning candle.
General Buxhöwden seemed not to listen.
General Buxhöwden did not wish to be thought to listen.
Milorádovich sat opposite General Weyrother.
Milorádovich's eyes were glistening wide-open and fixed upon General Weyrother.
Milorádovich's mustache was twisted upwards.
Milorádovich was in a military pose.
Milorádovich's elbows were turned outwards.
Milorádovich's hands were on his knees.
Milorádovich's shoulders were raised.
Milorádovich remained stubbornly silent.
Milorádovich gazed at General Weyrother's face.
Milorádovich turned away his eyes only when the Austrian chief of staff finished reading.
Milorádovich looked round significantly at the other generals.
It was unclear from Milorádovich's look whether he agreed with the arrangements.
It was unclear from Milorádovich's look whether he was satisfied with the arrangements.
Count Langeron sat next to General Weyrother.
Count Langeron had a subtle smile that never left his face.
Count Langeron gazed at his delicate fingers.
Count Langeron's fingers rapidly twirled a gold snuffbox with a portrait.
Count Langeron stopped the rotary motion of the snuffbox.
Count Langeron raised his head.
Count Langeron interrupted General Weyrother with inimical politeness.
Count Langeron wished to say something.
General Weyrother frowned angrily.
General Weyrother jerked his elbows.
General Weyrother said, "You can tell me your views later, but now be so good as to look at the map and listen."
Count Langeron lifted his eyes with an expression of perplexity.
Count Langeron turned round to Milorádovich seeking explanation.
Milorádovich's gaze was impressive but meaningless.
Milorádovich drooped his eyes sadly.
Milorádovich twirled his snuffbox again.
Milorádovich muttered "A geography lesson!" loudly enough to be heard.
Przebyszéwski held his hand to his ear toward General Weyrother.
Przebyszéwski had respectful but dignified politeness.
Przebyszéwski had the air of a man absorbed in attention.
Dohktúrov sat opposite General Weyrother.
Dohktúrov had an assiduous and modest mien.
Dohktúrov stooped over the outspread map.
Dohktúrov studied the dispositions and unfamiliar locality conscientiously.
Dohktúrov asked General Weyrother several times to repeat words he had not clearly heard.
Dohktúrov asked General Weyrother several times to repeat difficult names of villages.
General Weyrother complied.
Dohktúrov noted down the repeated words and village names.
The reading lasted more than an hour.
Count Langeron brought his snuffbox to rest.
Count Langeron did not look at General Weyrother or anyone in particular.
Count Langeron began to say that it was difficult to carry out such a plan in which the enemy’s position was assumed to be known.
Count Langeron said that the enemy’s position might not be known because the enemy was in movement.
Count Langeron's objections were valid.
Count Langeron's chief aim was to show General Weyrother that he had to do not with fools but with men who could teach him something in military matters.
General Weyrother had read his dispositions with as much self-confidence as if addressing school children.
The monotonous sound of General Weyrother's voice ceased.
Kutúzov opened his eye.
Kutúzov opened his eye as a miller wakes up when the soporific drone of the mill wheel is interrupted.
Kutúzov listened to what Count Langeron said.
Kutúzov remarked, "So you are still at that silly business!"
Kutúzov quickly closed his eye again.
Kutúzov let his head sink still lower.
Count Langeron argued that Bonaparte might easily attack instead of being attacked.
Count Langeron argued that this would render the whole plan perfectly worthless.
General Weyrother met all objections with a firm and contemptuous smile.
General Weyrother was evidently prepared beforehand to meet all objections.
General Weyrother said that if he could attack us, he would have done so today.
Count Langeron said, "So you think he is powerless?"
General Weyrother replied that he has forty thousand men at most.
General Weyrother had the smile of a doctor to whom an old wife wishes to explain the treatment of a case.
Count Langeron said that in that case the enemy is inviting his doom by awaiting our attack.
Count Langeron had a subtly ironical smile.
Count Langeron again glancing round for support to Milorádovich.
Milorádovich was near Count Langeron.
Milorádovich was at that moment evidently thinking of anything rather than what the generals were disputing about.
Milorádovich said, "Ma foi! tomorrow we shall see all that on the battlefield."
